00037 
00038 #ifndef CORELIB_DATAOBJECT_LOCK_FREE_HPP
00039 #define CORELIB_DATAOBJECT_LOCK_FREE_HPP
00040 
00041 #include "target.hpp"
00042 #include "os/oro_arch.h"
00043 
00044 namespace youbot {
00045 
00046     /**
00047      * @brief This DataObject is a Lock-Free implementation,
00048      * such that reads and writes can happen concurrently without priority
00049      * inversions.
00050      *
00051      * When there are more writes than reads, the last write will
00052      * be returned. The internal buffer can get full if too many
00053      * concurrent reads are taking to long. In that case, each new
00054      * read will read the element the previous read returned.
00055      *
00056      * @verbatim
00057      * The following Truth table applies when a Low Priority thread is
00058      * preempted by a High Priority thread :
00059      *
00060      *   L\H | Set | Get |
00061      *   Set | Ok  | Ok  |
00062      *   Get | Ok  | Ok  |
00063      *
00064      * legend : L : Low Priority thread
00065      *          H : High Priority thread
00066      *          Blk: Blocks High Priority thread (bad!)
00067      *          internal::NA : Not allowed !
00068      * @endverbatim
00069      * Further, multiple reads may occur before, during and after
00070      * a write operation simultaneously. The buffer needs readers+2*writers
00071      * elements to be guaranteed non blocking.
00072      * @ingroup PortBuffers
00073      */
00074     template<class T>
00075     class DataObjectLockFree{
00076     public:
00077         /**
00078          * The type of the data.
00079          */
00080         typedef T DataType;
00081 
00082         /**
00083          * @brief The maximum number of threads.
00084          *
00085          * When used in data flow, this is always 2.
00086          */
00087         const unsigned int MAX_THREADS; // = 2
00088     private:
00089         /**
00090          * Conversion of number of threads to size of buffer.
00091          */
00092         const unsigned int BUF_LEN; // = MAX_THREADS+2
00093 
00094         /**
00095          * Internal buffer structure.
00096          * Both the read and write pointers pointing to this struct
00097          * must be declared volatile, since they are modified in other threads.
00098          * I did not declare data as volatile,
00099          * since we only read/write it in secured buffers.
00100          */
00101         struct DataBuf {
00102             DataBuf()
00103                 : data(), counter(), next()
00104             {
00105                 oro_atomic_set(&counter, 0);
00106             }
00107             DataType data; mutable oro_atomic_t counter; DataBuf* next;
00108         };
00109 
00110         typedef DataBuf* volatile VolPtrType;
00111         typedef DataBuf  ValueType;
00112         typedef DataBuf* PtrType;
00113 
00114         VolPtrType read_ptr;
00115         VolPtrType write_ptr;
00116 
00117         /**
00118          * A 3 element Data buffer
00119          */
00120         DataBuf* data;
00121     public:
00122 
00123         /**
00124          * Construct a DataObjectLockFree by name.
00125          *
00126          * @param _name The name of this DataObject.
00127          * @param initial_value The initial value of this DataObject.
00128          */
00129         DataObjectLockFree( const T& initial_value = T(), unsigned int max_threads = 2 )
00130             : MAX_THREADS(max_threads), BUF_LEN( max_threads + 2),
00131               read_ptr(0),
00132               write_ptr(0)
00133         {
00134           data = new DataBuf[BUF_LEN];
00135           read_ptr = &data[0];
00136           write_ptr = &data[1];
00137             data_sample(initial_value);
00138         }
00139 
00140         ~DataObjectLockFree() {
00141             delete[] data;
00142         }
00143 
00144         /**
00145          * Get a copy of the data.
00146          * This method will allocate memory twice if data is not a value type.
00147          * Use Get(DataType&) for the non-allocating version.
00148          *
00149          * @return A copy of the data.
00150          */
00151         virtual DataType Get() const {DataType cache; Get(cache); return cache; }
00152 
00153         /**
00154          * Get a copy of the Data (non allocating).
00155          * If pull has reserved enough memory to store the copy,
00156          * no memory will be allocated.
00157          *
00158          * @param pull A copy of the data.
00159          */
00160         virtual void Get( DataType& pull ) const
00161         {
00162             PtrType reading;
00163             // loop to combine Read/Modify of counter
00164             // This avoids a race condition where read_ptr
00165             // could become write_ptr ( then we would read corrupted data).
00166             do {
00167                 reading = read_ptr;            // copy buffer location
00168                 oro_atomic_inc(&reading->counter); // lock buffer, no more writes
00169                 // XXX smp_mb
00170                 if ( reading != read_ptr )     // if read_ptr changed,
00171                     oro_atomic_dec(&reading->counter); // better to start over.
00172                 else
00173                     break;
00174             } while ( true );
00175             // from here on we are sure that 'reading'
00176             // is a valid buffer to read from.
00177             pull = reading->data;               // takes some time
00178             // XXX smp_mb
00179             oro_atomic_dec(&reading->counter);       // release buffer
00180         }
00181 
00182         /**
00183          * Set the data to a certain value (non blocking).
00184          *
00185          * @param push The data which must be set.
00186          */
00187         virtual void Set( const DataType& push )
00188         {
00189             /**
00190              * This method can not be called concurrently (only one
00191              * producer). With a minimum of 3 buffers, if the
00192              * write_ptr+1 field is not occupied, it will remain so
00193              * because the read_ptr is at write_ptr-1 (and can
00194              * not increment the counter on write_ptr+1). Hence, no
00195              * locking is needed.
00196              */
00197             // writeout in any case
00198             write_ptr->data = push;
00199             PtrType wrote_ptr = write_ptr;
00200             // if next field is occupied (by read_ptr or counter),
00201             // go to next and check again...
00202             while ( oro_atomic_read( &write_ptr->next->counter ) != 0 || write_ptr->next == read_ptr )
00203                 {
00204                     write_ptr = write_ptr->next;
00205                     if (write_ptr == wrote_ptr)
00206                         return; // nothing found, to many readers !
00207                 }
00208 
00209             // we will be able to move, so replace read_ptr
00210             read_ptr  = wrote_ptr;
00211             write_ptr = write_ptr->next; // we checked this in the while loop
00212         }
00213 
00214         virtual void data_sample( const DataType& sample ) {
00215             // prepare the buffer.
00216             for (unsigned int i = 0; i < BUF_LEN-1; ++i) {
00217                 data[i].data = sample;
00218                 data[i].next = &data[i+1];
00219             }
00220             data[BUF_LEN-1].data = sample;
00221             data[BUF_LEN-1].next = &data[0];
00222         }
00223     };
00224 }
00225 
00226 #endif
